item.title: Buffett Inspires Retail Investors to Bet on Japan Trading Houses
item.description: Japan’s retail investors have started to place their bets on trading house stocks, heavily backed by Berkshire Hathaway Inc.’s legendary investor Warren Buffett, eyeing strong business models and stellar shareholder returns.
item.dc:creator: Aya Wagatsuma, Toshiro Hasegawa

item.title: Asian Stock Futures Buoyed by US Jobs Surprise: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian stocks will likely draw support from US data showing the country’s labor market is holding up despite concerns about risks stemming from President Donald Trump’s tariff war. US shares and the dollar rose.
item.dc:creator: Rob Verdonck

media:content.media:description: Signage for Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd. (HKEx) at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, Sept. 17, 2024. Shares of Chinese appliance maker Midea Group Co. rose in their Hong Kong debut after the city’s biggest listing in three years saw robust demand and revived hopes of a turnaround for its struggling market.

item.title: BlackRock Escapes Texas Oil-Boycott List After ESG Retreat
item.description: BlackRock Inc. was removed from Texas’ blacklist of companies that boycott fossil fuels, ending a three-year standoff over the environmental policies of the world’s largest asset manager.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Moran

media:content.media:description: An oil drilling rig in Midland, Texas, US, on Thursday, March 2, 2023. Thousands of miles away from the turmoil on Wall Street, Midland, Texas that ranked No.1 in the US for inflation just over a year ago has since ceded that title – only to lay claim to a different one: the country’s pay-raise capital.

item.title: Data Centers Added $9.4 Billion in Costs on Biggest US Grid
item.description: The rapid development of data centers connected to the largest US electric grid raised costs by $9.4 billion, an expense that consumers from Illinois to Washington, D.C., will see reflected in their utility bills starting this month.
item.dc:creator: Naureen S Malik, Mark Chediak

media:content.media:description: A power substation near a the LC1 CloudHQ data center in Ashburn, Virginia, US, on Wednesday, March 27, 2024. Amazon.com Inc. plans to spend almost $150 billion in the coming 15 years on data centers, giving the cloud-computing giant the firepower to handle an expected explosion in demand for artificial intelligence applications and other digital services.

item.title: Alberta Fire Threat Stabilizes as Rain Slows Blazes’ Growth
item.description: Alberta’s wildfire threat stabilized as rain slowed the growth of some blazes and one oil sands operator resumed operation after shutting down last week.
item.dc:creator: Robert Tuttle, Brian K Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from Edith Lake wildfire SWF076, which forced the evacuation of the nearby town of Swan Hills, Alberta, Canada.

item.title: Chinese Firms Brush Off US Tariff Risks With Domestic Confidence
item.description: When US President Donald Trump took aim at China with record tariffs, the country’s firms shrugged it off.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and a container ship at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. China and the US agreed to temporarily lower tariffs levied against each other's products — the first major de-escalation in the trade row that was touted by US President Donald Trump as a "total reset" of bilateral ties.

item.title: AMC Theaters to Run Even More Commercials Before Movies Play
item.description: AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. has agreed to run more advertising in its theaters, ending its yearslong opposition to commercials that come right before each movie.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Buckley

media:content.media:description: A concessions stand at an AMC movie theater in New York.

item.title: Latin America Currencies Dragged Down by Dollar; BRL Rallies
item.description: A surge in the dollar dragged down a wide array of emerging-market currencies Tuesday, while developing-market stocks advanced after two days of losses.
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Butler, Leda Alvim

item.title: Bank of America's Retail Outlook Amid Trade Uncertainty
item.description: Lorraine Hutchinson, Bank of America, Retail Analyst speaks with Romaine Bostick about retail outlook amid trade uncertainty. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Shoe Designer Sophia Webster Not Seeing Big Tariff Impact
item.description: Luxury shoe designer Sophia Webster discusses the impact of tariffs and inflation on the luxury goods market with Katie Greifeld and Romaine Bostick on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Apollo’s Zito Sees AI Boom Powering Private Credit Growth
item.description: Rapid-fire advancements in artificial intelligence make even predicting what next month will look like a challenge. That uncertainty is an opening for private credit, which has the adaptability needed to fund the fast-growing industry, according to John Zito at Apollo Global Management Inc.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fishlow, Rachel Graf

media:content.media:description: John Zito, partner and deputy chief investment officer of credit at Apollo Global Management Inc., during the Bloomberg Invest event in New York, US, on Tuesday, June 25, 2024. The conference invites leaders in asset management, banking, wealth, and private markets to track, dissect, and predict the future's greatest changes, risks and opportunities.

item.title: Stocks Gain on US Jobs Surprise | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: The Right And Left Are Teaming Up Against CEOs
item.description: One-time Democratic supporter Vani Hari is now a central figure in the Trump administration. It’s a sign that some more progressive figures are willing to ally with the right if it means furthering their agenda, says Bloomberg Opinion columnist Beth Kowitt. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Fed Lifts Wells Fargo Asset Cap
item.description: Wells Fargo has been released from a Federal Reserve asset cap that has restricted its size for over seven years, allowing the bank to pursue growth again. Sally Bakewell has more on “Bloomberg The Close.”

item.title: Tech Powers S&P’s Gains on AI Boost, Healthy Jobs Data, Earnings
item.description: US equities shrugged off initial jitters to extend its gains for a second straight session on Tuesday, buoyed by a report signaling a healthy job market and a string of positive corporate news.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.

item.title: Stocks Gain on US Jobs Surprise as Treasuries Fall: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street traders drove stocks higher as data showed the US labor market is holding up despite concerns about risks stemming from President Donald Trump’s tariff war. Bonds fell. The dollar rose.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: The Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index edged down 0.2 point last month to 48.5. The ISM’s import measure dropped 7.2 points, one of the largest monthly slides on record, to 39.9. Mike McKee reports on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Corrects to show third month of contraction)

item.title: Why Dollar General Is One Big Tariff Winner
item.description: The retailers is running back the 2018/2019 playbook
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: A shopper inside a Dollar General store in the Queens borough of New York, US, on Tuesday, June 3, 2025. Dollar General Corp. surged after increasing its annual guidance following a first quarter that topped projections. Photographer: Adam Gray/Bloomberg

item.title: BlackRock Ends Standoff With Texas Over ESG Policies
item.description: BlackRock Inc. was removed from Texas’ blacklist of companies that boycott fossil fuels, ending a three-year standoff over the environmental policies of the world’s largest asset manager. This means pension funds and other state-run investment accounts can buy BlackRock shares and work with the firm. Bloomberg's Danielle Moran explains on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Growing Use of Bitcoin Treasuries
item.description: Alyse Killeen, GP and managing partner of Stillmark, discusses why more companies are adding Bitcoin treasuries, as Trump Media raises over $2 billion for the strategy. Killeen joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Extends Gains as Canada Wildfires Offset OPEC+ Output Hike
item.description: Oil rose for a second day as supply disruptions from Canada’s wildfires countered OPEC’s latest bumper supply increase.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: A pumpjack in Martin County, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch. Photographer: Justin Hamel/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Memecoin Wallet Spurs Divide Among Family’s Crypto Camps
item.description: There appears to be a divide among the various crypto-entities affiliated with President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Olga Kharif

media:content.media:description: A cartoon image of US President-elect Donald Trump with cryptocurrency tokens, depicted in front of the White House to mark his inauguration, displayed at a Coinhero store in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, Jan. 20, 2025. Bitcoin reached an all-time high as the US prepares to inaugurate pro-crypto President-elect Donald Trump. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: Industrial Metals End Mixed as Traders Mull China and US Data
item.description: Industrial metals finished mixed as concerns about China’s economy were tempered by signs of a healthy jobs market in the US.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell, Mark Burton

media:content.media:description: Iron ore falls onto stockpiles at the Fortescue Metals Group Ltd. Cloudbreak mine in the Pilbara region of Western Australia, Australia, on Tuesday, Oct. 17, 2023. Chinese demand for Australian iron ore will remain strong despite the nation’s disappointing post-pandemic recovery, according to Fortescue Metals, the world’s fourth-biggest producer. Photographer: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg

item.title: Texas Stock Exchange on Track to Debut in 2026
item.description: The Texas Stock Exchange is filing its Form 1 registration with the SEC to register as a national securities exchange. Reports indicate it has secured over $161 million dollars in funding as it aims for a 2026 launch. Jeb Hensarling, Texas Stock Exchange Strategic Adviser and Former Chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the new exchange. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Joby, Saudi Group Eye Air Taxi Deal
item.description: Joby is looking toward a possible expansion throughout the Middle East. The California-based company is working toward an agreement to sell as many as 200 of its air taxis through Abdul Latif Jameel, a major Saudi Arabian investor. In an interview for Wall Street Week, CEO JoeBen Bevirt says, “We think that, over time, the market in Saudi is substantially larger than that. But this is the first chunk.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Investing in the Energy Future
item.description: The energy transition will reward specialized investors, says John Tough, managing partner at Energize Capital. Tough discusses the firm’s latest $430 million fundraising round with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Peru Says Large-Scale Informal Copper Mining Exists And Could Grow
item.description: Peru’s government is acknowledging for the first time the existence of large-scale informal mining of copper, warning that high prices could see the activity grow in the near future.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

media:content.media:description: An informal mining truck in the town of Pamputa, Peru.

item.title: Meta Invests in Nuclear to Fuel AI Ambitions | Bloomberg Markets 6/3/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg Markets" follows the market moves across every global asset class and discusses the biggest issues for Wall Street. Today's guests; Dimensional Fund Advisors Chairman and Co-Founder David Booth, Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow and Lily Meir (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Meta to Meet AI Power Demand with Nuclear Power
item.description: Meta has agreed to buy nuclear power from Constellation Energy to run its artificial intelligence ambitions. Jefferies Analyst Brent Thill talks about the impact of the plan with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Tesla Alum Targets Grid Transformation with Heron
item.description: Long-serving Tesla executive Drew Baglino has launched a new startup to address a major bottleneck in the energy sector transformers. Baglino discusses his company's technology and his experience at Tesla with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Galaxy’s Nasdaq Debut Clears the Path for Canada-US Listings
item.description: Galaxy Digital Inc.’s US debut is a homecoming for the Toronto Stock Exchange-listed, New York-based company. For Canadian firms on the TSX, it could be the start of reversing a multi-year trend of domestic firms choosing to trade closer to where they’re based.
item.dc:creator: Geoffrey Morgan

media:content.media:description: Michael Novogratz, founder and chief executive officer of Galaxy Digital LP, during the iConnections Global Alts 2024 event in Miami Beach, Florida, US, on Tuesday, Jan. 30, 2024. Speakers at the event will share insights and strategies related to alternative investments.
